intro: Halothamnus heptapotamicus, commonly known as the seven-potamo grass, is a flowering plant native to the Mediterranean region. It is a member of the Amaranthaceae family, which includes many species adapted to arid environments. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is characterized by its dense, tufted growth habit. Its small, inconspicuous flowers are clustered in spike-like inflorescences, and it produces small, dry fruits that contain single seeds. Halothamnus heptapotamicus is well adapted to withstand drought and high temperatures, making it a resilient species in its native habitat.
